articles.title: Coding Notes
articles.contents:
Contents
Basic R Operations
Graphing in R
Simulations in R

Basic R Operations
There are a voluminous amount of resources on R online. Here is a very minimal crash course.
Data Types
R has six basic data types. The four most common types we work with are vectors, lists, matrices, and data frames.
Vectors



Vectors can also be characters (strings in other languages)



Lists

[[1]]
[1] 1 2 3 4 5

[[2]]
[1] "A" "B" "C"

Matrices

     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
[1,]    1    2    3    4
[2,]    5    6    7    8
[3,]    9   10   11   12
[4,]   13   14   15   16

Data Frames

  var1 var2
1    a    1
2    b    2
3    c    3
4    d    4
5    e    5

Subsetting
Control Operations
Functions
Graphing in R
Simulations in R
The Birthday Problem

articles.title: Matrix Algebra in R
articles.description: A Crash Course in Matrix Algebra using R
articles.contents:
Contents
Vectors
Vector Addition and Multiplication
Matrices
Ordinary Least Squares

Vectors
The simplest way to represent vectors in R is by using the vector data structure.


x = c(-1.1, 0.0, 3.6, -7.2)
length(x) ## 4 

[1] 4

Block and stacked vectors
In addition to creating vectors, we can concatenate vectors together to produce blocked and stacked vectors using the c() function.


x = c(1,-2)
y = c(1,1,0)
z = c(x,y)
z

[1]  1 -2  1  1  0

Some special vectors
The Zeros vector is a default behavior of creating a vector with a given length.


z = numeric(3)
z

[1] 0 0 0

The Ones vector can be made by way of the rep() function.


o = rep(1,3)
o

[1] 1 1 1

Vector Addition and Multiplication
If x and y are vectors of the same size, then x+y and x-y give their element wise sum and difference respectively. R by default computes most vector operations element wise.


x = c(1,2,3)
y = c(100,200,300)
x+y

[1] 101 202 303

Scalar Multiplication and division
If a is a number and x is a vector, then we can express the scalar vector product as either a*x or x*a


a = 2 
x = c(1,2,3)
a*x

[1] 2 4 6

x*a

[1] 2 4 6

Using what we’ve learned to confirm the distributive property
The distributive property \(\beta(a+b) = \beta a + \beta b\) holds for any two n-vector a and b and any scalar \(\beta\).


set.seed(123)
a = c(3,5,6)
b = c(2,4,9)
beta = 5
lhs = beta*(a+b)
rhs = beta*a + beta*b
print(lhs)

[1] 25 45 75

print(rhs)

[1] 25 45 75

lhs == rhs

[1] TRUE TRUE TRUE

Inner Product
The inner product of n-vector x and y is denoted \(x^Ty\)


x = c(1,2,3,4)
y = c(3,4,6,7)

## t() is the transpose function in R
t(x)%*% y

     [,1]
[1,]   57

Matrices
A matrix \(\textbf{X}\) is an \(m\) x \(n\) data structure that is a rectangular array of scalar numbers. The numbers \(x_{ij}\) are components or elements of \(\textbf{X}\). The transpose of a matrix is the \(n\) x \(m\) matrix \(\textbf{X}'\)


## Creating a matrix in R 
X = matrix(seq(1,16,1), 
           nrow = 4, 
           byrow = T)
X

     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
[1,]    1    2    3    4
[2,]    5    6    7    8
[3,]    9   10   11   12
[4,]   13   14   15   16

We can also create matrices from vectors or from data frames


## Equivalent to above but with vectors 
X2 = rbind(1:4, 5:8,9:12,13:16)
X2

     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
[1,]    1    2    3    4
[2,]    5    6    7    8
[3,]    9   10   11   12
[4,]   13   14   15   16



## via a data frame 
df = data.frame(
  x = 1:4,
  y = 5:8,
  z = 9:12,
  w = 13:16
)
X3 = as.matrix(df)
X3

     x y  z  w
[1,] 1 5  9 13
[2,] 2 6 10 14
[3,] 3 7 11 15
[4,] 4 8 12 16

Additional Definitions
The transpose in R


X_transpose = t(X)
X_transpose

     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
[1,]    1    5    9   13
[2,]    2    6   10   14
[3,]    3    7   11   15
[4,]    4    8   12   16

A diagonal matrix with all elements not on the diagonal equal to zero is a diagonal matrix. By default, R creates an identity matrix with the diag() function.


dM = diag(4)
dM

     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
[1,]    1    0    0    0
[2,]    0    1    0    0
[3,]    0    0    1    0
[4,]    0    0    0    1

The trace of a matrix is the sum of the diagonal elements
\[trace(X) = \sum_{i=1}^n x_{ii}\]


matrix_trace = function(mat){
  return(sum(diag(mat)))
}

matrix_trace(X)

[1] 34

Matrix Arithmetic
Addition and subtraction of matrices of the same order are performed element by element. Scalar multiplication is element by element


A = matrix(data = seq(1,9,1), nrow = 3, byrow = T)
B = matrix(data = seq(1,9,1), nrow = 3, byrow = T)
A+B

     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]    2    4    6
[2,]    8   10   12
[3,]   14   16   18

Provided that the number of columns of A equals the number of rows of B, we can multiple A by B.


## To get the appropriate multiplication, we wrap * in %*%
A%*%B

     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]   30   36   42
[2,]   66   81   96
[3,]  102  126  150

Note that we can perform X’X in one of two ways.


t(A)%*%A 

     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]   66   78   90
[2,]   78   93  108
[3,]   90  108  126

## same but can be slightly faster 
crossprod(A)

     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]   66   78   90
[2,]   78   93  108
[3,]   90  108  126

Ordinary Least Squares
The simplest linear model expresses the dependence of a dependent or response variable y on independent variables \(x_1,.., x_p\) and is usually written \(y = X\beta + \epsilon\). See the Lecture Notes for more details on the properties of this model.
Define the design matrix as the \(n \times p\) matrix of independent variables \(x_1,..,x_p\) and assume that the first columns is a column of ones and that the design matrix has full rank. Then the usual OLS estimator is defined as \((X'X)^-1X'Y\)


beta_estimator = function(X,y){
  X = cbind(rep(1,nrow(X)), X)
  betas = solve(t(X)%*%X)%*%t(X)%*%y
  return(betas)
}

## example data 
x1 = rnorm(10000)
x2 = rnorm(10000)
y = 2*x1 + 4*x2 + runif(10000)

X = cbind(x1, x2)
beta_estimator(X,y)

        [,1]
   0.4997833
x1 1.9971656
x2 4.0020879
